stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on building out Course 14’s “craft materials” theme by creating and testing new environmental assets (clouds, pins, cardboard trees/mountains, cups, lamps) and outlining the course’s star missions. He also checks N64 performance, discusses engine constraints (ROM size, RSP bottlenecks, F3DEX3), and shares a concrete versioning plan for emulator vs real-hardware support.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a full Course 14 star outline, shows N64 performance targets/tradeoffs for new visuals, clarifies ROM-size limits and recent engine work (F3DEX3), and lays out a specific release/version strategy where later updates may intentionally outpace emulator support.

findings.summary: Course 14’s core identity is a “craft level” built entirely from household craft materials (cardboard, paper cutouts/doodles, pins, plastic, etc.), with NPCs intentionally portrayed as robotic/not-real to avoid heavier story beats.

Kaze outlines Course 14’s current star structure: (1) help a Yoshi doodle by defeating “squirrels” (crafted enemies), (2) rescue a Toad doodle on a mountain who gifts a star, (3) fetch a yellow crayon for Luigi and physically draw over an outline on paper to create a star, (4) enter a large cardboard box leading to an interior platforming section, (5) a toy (weasel-ball style) guards a red-coin area (and he mentions an “8-bit pipe to Mario Paint” idea in this context).
The “draw with a crayon” mission is designed as an understandable interaction: Kaze plans to add a trace/outline so players know where to draw, reducing puzzle ambiguity.
Kaze confirms a hard ROM size limit of 64 MB for the project.
He tests performance on N64 and targets at least 30 FPS; he observes dips (down to ~25 FPS in one spot) tied to visual density (cloud count) and notes he can raise FPS by reducing clouds.

Engine/renderer work is ongoing; he states they recently imported F3DEX3, and describes a shift in bottlenecks: once memory throughput is optimized, the RSP (not the CPU) becomes the limiting factor, and he personally hasn’t “programmed the RSP” deeply yet.
Zeina has been testing Course 13 movement/physics for intuitiveness, and is also working on Course 13’s outside area; Kaze expresses increased confidence after her playtesting feedback.

Biobak provides optimization feedback via chat; Kaze reacts to Biobak reporting ~400 polygons removed from a key area (trees removed/replaced), and asks whether the change is a better replacement or simply lower poly.

Kaze distinguishes the craft level from a “kid’s room” diorama: he wants it to feel like something intentionally crafted, not random children’s toys (e.g., he rejects putting LEGO/cereal boxes and decides against books after weighing theme fit vs comedic fake titles).

Overworld direction is stated: it’s planned as “Yoshi’s fruit islands,” with progression described as exploring deeper into the island(s) over time; Zeina has begun sketches but there is no finalized layout yet.

Kaze lays out a phased release plan tied to hardware/emulator compatibility: Version 1 will run on emulator and N64; Version 1.1 will still run on both; Version 1.2 would become N64-only, with the stated attitude that emulators should “catch up” afterward.
findings.quote: We release version 1: runs on emulator and N64… then 1.2 is only N64… emulators will then technologically have to catch up with the game.

findings.summary: He contrasts his older hack design mindset (Lost Impact) with a more player-experience focus now: in the past he prioritized novelty/ideas over fun, inserting ideas immediately to avoid “being lazy,” which he believes made parts of Lost Impact frustrating or full of bizarre decisions.
findings.quote: When I made Last Impact… my thought was never ‘can I make this fun,’ it was always just ‘I have an idea, I’ll put it in.’

findings.summary: He notes a widescreen-support dilemma: emulator widescreen and real N64 widescreen modes differ, complicating a single build that supports both cleanly.

biobak.summary: Biobak reports a significant geometry reduction (~400 polygons) in a main area by removing surrounding trees (implying optimization or replacement work).

Biobak agrees with Kaze’s direction that the pin assets look strong and reads the cardboard aesthetic as working; Kaze expects the level to improve once Biobak has more direct involvement/feedback on the overall look.

zeina.summary: Zeina playtests Course 13 movement/physics; her ability to navigate the new physics comfortably becomes Kaze’s evidence that the controls are intuitive.
Zeina is actively building Course 13’s outside area and has started sketches for the overworld layout.

findings.summary: Kaze states Sauraen is currently working on deeper RSP-side improvements; Kaze anticipates Sauraen will produce “cool things,” especially relevant now that the RSP is emerging as the primary bottleneck after other optimizations (and following the F3DEX3 import).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: When I made Last Impact… my thought was never ‘can I make this fun,’ it was always just ‘I have an idea, I’ll put it in.’
memorable_quotes.context: A candid reflection on earlier creative instincts vs current design priorities—useful for the documentary’s theme of learning how to ‘respect’ the original while making something new and playable.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: We release version 1… runs on emulator and N64… then 1.2 is only N64… emulators will then technologically have to catch up with the game.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear statement of the team’s long-term stance on authenticity vs accessibility, and a concrete plan for release milestones.

key_stories.title: Course 14 concept and star lineup (craft-material world)
key_stories.summary: Kaze establishes Course 14 as a handcrafted diorama world built from cardboard, paper, pins, plastic cups, and doodle NPCs. He then enumerates a draft set of star missions, centered on simple, readable interactions (help NPCs, a crayon-carry-and-draw objective, a box interior sub-area, and a toy-guarded red-coin section).
key_stories.challenge: Creating a cohesive theme that feels like intentional craftwork (not random toys), while still producing varied, understandable objectives.
key_stories.process: Rapidly prototypes assets to match the aesthetic, iterates on readability (e.g., adding a drawing outline), and sanity-checks feasibility/performance on N64 hardware.
key_stories.outcome: A working thematic direction with a concrete star plan, plus identified next steps: finalize assets, arrange level layout after an art test, and tune visual density for stable FPS.
key_stories.key_quote: This is the craft level. It’s made out of craft materials, the whole thing.

key_stories.title: Performance-first iteration: cloud density and 30 FPS target
key_stories.summary: While testing visuals like volumetric-looking cloud obstacles, Kaze checks real-hardware performance and sees dips below his 30 FPS target. He frames the solution as a straightforward tradeoff: reduce cloud count to recover frame rate.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing a distinctive look (clouds and shading) against strict N64 performance constraints.
key_stories.process: Runs live framerate tests, identifies the expensive element, and proposes parameter reduction (cloud density) as the immediate fix.
key_stories.outcome: A clear optimization lever is identified early in the art pass, helping prevent later rework when the level fills in with more assets.
key_stories.key_quote: I want at least 30 FPS… I can very easily increase the FPS by just reducing the amount of clouds.

key_stories.title: Release plan that prioritizes real N64 over emulator parity
key_stories.summary: Kaze proposes a staged compatibility roadmap: ship a baseline release that works on both emulator and N64, then later move toward an N64-first (even N64-only) target where emulators may not keep up immediately. This reframes the project from ‘ROM hack that happens to run on hardware’ into something closer to a true N64 game with modern features.
key_stories.challenge: Supporting both emulators and original hardware as the engine becomes more advanced and potentially relies on behavior emulators don’t yet replicate.
key_stories.process: Defines explicit version milestones (1.0, 1.1, 1.2) tied to compatibility guarantees and sets expectations for the community.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete policy that can guide testing, marketing, and technical decision-making—and a likely future inflection point for player access.
key_stories.key_quote: At that point we have enough emulator compatibility that we can just say, ‘fuck it, we’re making an N64 game.’

open_questions.topic: Course 14 mission set and final structure
open_questions.context: Kaze lists five star ideas plus mentions of red coins and an “8-bit pipe to Mario Paint” concept, but it’s unclear how many stars Course 14 will ultimately have and which ideas are placeholders.
questions: How many missions/stars will Course 14 ship with, and which of today’s ideas are ‘locked’ versus experimental?
What exactly is the “8-bit pipe to Mario Paint” idea—an Easter egg, a sub-area, a warp, or a full mechanic?
How will the team keep the crayon-drawing mission readable without turning it into a slow puzzle or frustrating carry quest?

open_questions.topic: Course 13 status and what remains before it is considered finished
open_questions.context: Kaze calls Course 13 “mostly done,” shows improvements done off-stream, and says Zeina is working on the outside area; he also references it internally as “Cross13.”
questions: What is “Cross13” (working title, layout concept, or a specific sub-area), and why did it become a focal point in prior streams?
What specific tasks are left for Course 13 (art polish, collision pass, enemy/mission scripting, performance, camera)?
What feedback did Zeina give from her physics/movement test—were changes made as a result?

open_questions.topic: RSP bottleneck, F3DEX3 import, and Sauraen’s current work
open_questions.context: Kaze says F3DEX3 was recently imported and that the RSP has become the bottleneck after optimizing memory throughput; he notes Sauraen is working on RSP improvements now.
questions: What did importing F3DEX3 concretely unlock for RTYI (features, performance, pipeline changes), and what broke or had to be refactored?
What specific RSP-side improvements is Sauraen targeting (new display-list features, microcode tweaks, faster transforms, custom effects)?
How does the team decide when to prioritize RSP work vs ‘simpler’ content-side optimizations like reducing cloud counts or polygon budgets?

open_questions.topic: ROM size cap rationale and content budgeting
open_questions.context: Kaze states the project is capped at 64 MB, implying a deliberate constraint for assets/levels.
questions: Why 64 MB specifically (hardware/flashcart constraints, loading architecture, personal target, distribution format)?
How do you budget the 64 MB across textures, music, cutscenes/voice, and level geometry—do you have per-course budgets?
Have any major ideas been cut or redesigned specifically because of the 64 MB limit?

open_questions.topic: Overworld design ownership and integration with progression
open_questions.context: Kaze describes the overworld conceptually as Yoshi’s fruit islands with deeper exploration, and says Zeina has sketches but nothing final.
questions: What is the intended moment-to-moment overworld experience (hub with gates, exploration with secrets, mission-based entrances, story beats)?
What parts of the overworld are Zeina leading (layout, visuals, animation, theming), and what parts does Kaze intend to prototype in-engine?
How will the overworld visually communicate ‘deeper into the island’ progression—new biomes, elevation, lighting, or narrative markers?
